title: ‎The Data Exchange with Ben Lorica on Apple Podcasts

last_post.content:
Peter Norvig and Alfred Spector on their acclaimed new book on data science, and recent trends in AI.

Subscribe: Apple • Spotify • Stitcher • Google • AntennaPod • Podcast Addict • Amazon •  RSS.

Peter Norvig (of Google and Stanford) and Alfred Spector (of MIT) are part of the team of authors behind the must-read book Data Science in Context: Foundations, Challenges, Opportunities. We discussed their recent book and tool a deep dive into their Data Science Analysis Rubric, and we also talked about a trending topics in AI including looming regulations, synthetic data, and Large Language and Foundation Models.

Subscribe to the Gradient Flow Newsletter

Make sure you read and share their new book! As I noted in a recent newsletter Data Science In Context is a valuable resource for anyone looking to use data science and AI in real-world applications. I encourage you to check it out and share it with your colleagues (more details below).

Interview highlights – key sections from the video version:

UX and visualization, and data science
Why they wrote the book “Data Science in Context”, and who is the target reader
Data Science Analysis Rubric: Seven major considerations for determining data science’s applicability to a proposed solution
Benefits of using their Data Science Analysis Rubric – relationship with software engineering best practices
Unreasonable effectiveness of data – a status update
Looming AI regulations: EU AI Act and more
Automation in data science
Synthetic Data: strengths and limitations
Software Supply Chain attacks: the importance of PyPi
Large Language Models and Foundation Models
The nature of Data Science courses five years from now


 

Use the 30% Discount Code: LORICA30

Buy Now

A long toot for this #FollowFriday, my first one on this instance.

I find that #Mastodon’s coverage is surprisingly good on a number of topics. With more people joining by the day, it is getting better very rapidly.

I would like to mention a few here:
- #photography, especially #naturephotography
- #astronomy and #astrophysics
- #climatechange and #sustainability
- #Ukraine and the #war with #Russia

I’m happy to recommend specific accounts here. I would suggest, if you are interested in any of those #subjects, that you first run #followgraph on my main handle (fog@newsie.social), to identify the relevant ones.

If you don’t know followgraph, have a look at this fantastic tool, which was created by @gabipurcaru to enhance #discoverability: https://followgraph.vercel.app/

There are others areas, for which I need to spend more time to identify interesting accounts.

-#architecture, particularly #modernism and #contemporary #architects.
@concretelibraries is great. Do you have others you like?

- #arts, notably #finearts, #museums and current #exhibitions. There is @NationalGallery. A number of famous painters have their own bot, broadcasting images of their work, often without context. Who else would you recommend?

- #cinema: I have a couple of good handles on the history of the 7th art: @Cinematologists, @cinemaetpol (in French), @MoviesSilently. I could use more, notably on #currentmovies, #directors and #actors.

-#jazz #music
I’ve recently discovered a few good handles for #classicalmusic. I would love suggestions for jazz and #blues.

I've been tossing around the terms "enumerated kind of value" and "specified kind of value". It's worth noting that "enumerated value" actually has a meaning within Inform, one of the "kinds of kind", along with value, sayable value, and arithmetic value that are permitted to describe parameters in phrase definitions.

"specified kind of value" has no official standing.
